description: September 14, 2020: With Bulletin N. 262, the Italian Ministry of Health announced that the Italian Minister of Health, Roberto Speranza, has attended the 70th session of the WHO Regional Committee for Europe (RC70), organised by the WHO Regional Office for Europe, on September 14 and 15, 2020. Representatives of 53 countries in the WHO European Region have attended. Representatives of WHO partners such as United Nations agencies and other intergovernmental organisations and regional networks, were also present. Non-State actors (NSAs) in official relations with WHO and regional NSAs accredited by the Regional Committee, have followed the webstream and had the opportunity to submit video and written statements in advance. The key health issues and future plans have been discussed, particularly on themes regarding the response to the COVID-19 pandemic and lessons learned from the pandemic, both globally and regionally.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: Cooperation among different jurisdictional entities (e.g. treaties or agreements among countries or provinces)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory (Unspecified/Implied)

description: The Government of Romania, through the Authority for the Digitization of Romania, and the non-governmental organization Code for Romania launched the online platform COVID-19 Official News (stirioficiale.ro) on Monday, 16.03.2020. The aim of this platform is to fight misinformation and fake news in order to rebuild trust with the state. The site only publishes reliable sources such as press releases from the Romanian government

compliance: Voluntary/Recommended but No Penalties

description: On March 10th, 2020, the Romanian Ministry of Health announce that the study programs of exchange type of experience and internships in hospitals of students and pupils of post-secondary health schools are stopped, if they were not started before March 9 this year. Postsecondary internships for medical students and experience programs for healthcare and sanitation workers are also suspended if they were not started before March 9.

description: As a result of the current epidemiological context, the Ministry of Health announces to those interested that the examinations and competitions organized by the ministry are postponed. Thus, the exam for obtaining the title of specialist doctor - the session of March 19, 2020 and the competitions for the position in the health units are postponed until a date that will be announced later.

description:
On April 27th 2020, Romanian President Klaus Iohannis stated in a press release by the National Liberal Party that schools would remain closed for most students until the end of the school year- June 12th 2020. Online learning would continue for these students.

Students in the 8th and 12th grades could come into school from the period of June 2nd to June 12th to prepare for national exams for high school and university. Class sizes were restricted to a maximum of 10 students, and they would only be at school for 3 hours a day, maximum. Exams would continue with social distancing measures observed.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: "The Romanian authorities are preparing for a scenario in which schools in the country will remain closed in September when the new school year will start. Courses could thus move online, and the local education system should be digitized by then, education minister Monica Anisie said in TV interviews over the weekend.  About 250,000 of the 3 million students enrolled in primary and secondary education in Romania don't have access to technology and can't participate in online courses, the education minister said at Digi24.  The Romanian authorities closed all schools and kindergartens in the country on March 11 to stop the spreading of the COVID-19 epidemic. The decision was enforced before the state of emergency was decreed in the country, on March 16.  On April 27, president Klaus Iohannis announced that schools would remain closed in Romania until the end of the school year."

description: Romanian schools scheduled to re-open from 14th September, 2020. Schools can use three learning models when the new school year starts, depending on each locality's coronavirus situation. The three scenarios are: in-person classes, the hybrid model (alternating virtual learning and in-class learning), and online/at-home only learning.

description: Romanian Ministry of Education and Research announced on 22nd of October, 2020, that 2401 education units are listed to work in red scenario (Scenario 3), involving the participation only in online activities. 4891 education units are listed in Scenario 2, meaning partial return (by rotation) in compliance with all rules of protection and 10364 in Scenario 1 (daily participation in compliance with all health protection rules).  According to the Order of the Minister of Education and Research and the Minister of Health 5487/1494/01.09.2020, one of the three operating scenarios is the cumulative incidence rate, respectively the total number of new cases in the last 14 days compared to 1000 inhabitants.

description: According to the Romanian ministerial order 5972/8.11.20, starting on 9.11.20, the teaching activities that require the physical presence of preschoolers and students in preschool, primary, secondary, high school and post-secondary education units are suspended for a period of 30 days. The teaching activities will be carried out online, according to the Framework Methodology on conducting teaching activities through technology and the Internet, as well as for the processing of personal data, approved by order of the Ministry of Education and Research 5545/2020.

description: Schools in Romania will reopen from 8-Feb-21 but under different scenarios according to their local epidemiological situations. Under the green scenario, which corresponds to an infection rate of under 1.5 per 1,000 inhabitants (over a 14-day period), all students return to school. In the yellow scenario (infection rate of between 1.5 and 3), only kindergarten and primary school (I-IV grades) pupils return to school together with students in the eighth and twelfth grades, who have to prepare for the national exams. In the red scenario (infection rate of over 3), only kindergartens and primary schools will stay open. Localities with infection rates of over 6 per 1,000 residents will remain under lockdown, with schools closed, according to the plan announced by president Iohannis.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
institution_status: Preschool or childcare facilities allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Other Health Monitoring
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory (Unspecified/Implied)

description: According to the Romanian ministerial order no.3.235/93/04.02.2021, depending on the incidence rate by localities, the activity of the educational units will be organized, starting with 8th of February, in three scenarios: a) Physical presence for all categories, if the cumulative incidence in the last 14 days in the locality is less or equal to 1/1000 people; b) physical presence for preschool, primary, 8th, 12th and 13th classes, and online presence for the other classes, for a incidence less or equal with 3/1000; c) Online presence for all categories, except preschool and primary units, if incidence is higher than 3/1000.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: According to the Romanian ministerial order no.3755/29.04.2021 (which extends order no. 3235/93/2021), if the cumulative incidence of cases, in a locality for the last 14 days, is lower than 1/1000 inhabitants, the participation in classes will be physical presence for all preschoolers, primary school students and other groups of students. If it is higher than 1/1000, all activities will be online, except the students from grades 8th, 12th, and 13th classes.

description: On May 12, 2021, national assessments in Romania began for grades 2, 4 and 6 for the school year 2020-2021. All tests take place with physical presence, regardless of the scenarios in which the schools are located.  The rooms in which these assessments are held are, as a rule, those in which students carry out their activities on a regular basis. These are adapted in advance, as appropriate, according to the planned test, by eliminating any teaching materials that could influence students.

description: Romania imposed a curfew starting on the 21st of March 2020. In the time interval 22.00 - 06.00, the movement of persons outside the household is allowed only for medical purposes, work, acquiring goods to cover basic needs- including those of pets, caring for a child/elderly person, short physical activity trips including walking pets.In order to verify the reason for traveling in the professional interest, the persons are obliged to present, at the request of the competent authorities staff, the service card, the certificate issued by the employer or a declaration on their own responsibility or a declaration on their own responsibility, completed in advance.The declaration on one's own responsibility must include the name and surname, date of birth, residential address/ place of professional activity, reason for travel, date of completion and signature.The exceptions to these provisions are the personnel within the Presidential Administration, the Romanian Parliament, the Romanian Government, the Public Ministry, the institutions of the national defense system, public order and national security, the diplomatic corps and the personnel providing public utility services.

description:
Romania imposed a curfew starting on the 21st of March 2020. 
In the time interval 22.00 - 06.00, the movement of persons outside the household is allowed only for medical purposes, work, acquiring goods to cover basic needs- including those of pets, caring for a child/elderly person, short physical activity trips including walking pets.

In order to verify the reason for traveling in the professional interest, the persons are obliged to present, at the request of the competent authorities staff, the service card, the certificate issued by the employer or a declaration on their own responsibility or a declaration on their own responsibility, completed in advance.

The declaration on one's own responsibility must include the name and surname, date of birth, residential address/ place of professional activity, reason for travel, date of completion and signature.

The exceptions to these provisions are the personnel within the Presidential Administration, the Romanian Parliament, the Romanian Government, the Public Ministry, the institutions of the national defense system, public order and national security, the diplomatic corps and the personnel providing public utility services.

 UPDATE: The curfew was lifted on May 15th 2020
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: No the curfew times are always the same regardless of the day of the week
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time)
enforcer: National Government,Military,Police,Other (Please specify in the text box)

Travel for medical treatments, professional activities, and agricultural purposes are allowed irrespective of the time slots.

description: On November 5, 2020, Romania banned "the movement of persons outside the home / household between 23.00 - 05.00" with the exemption of traveling for professional interests, medical assistance, and justified reasons, such as caring for / accompanying the child, assisting the elderly, sick or disabled or the death of a family member. UPDATE: From March 25, 2021, curfew times are adapted: Where the cumulative 14-days incidence is over 4 and under or equal to 7.5 / 1000 residents, there is a curfew on Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays between 8 pm and 5 am, with the same exemptions applying. Where the cumulative 14-days incidence is over 7.5 / 1000 residents, there is a daily curfew between 8 pm and 5 am, with the same exemptions applying. From March 27, 6 pm, to March 28, 10 pm, curfews are suspended for the purpose of participating in Passover festivities. From April 3, 8 pm, to April 4, 2 am, curfews are suspended for the purpose of participating in worship services.

Romania, May 15, 2021:
The Romanian government imposes a curfew on regions where the cumulative 14-days incidence is over 4 and under or equal to 7.5 / 1000 residents which applies on Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays between 8 pm and 5 am. Exceptions exist Where the cumulative 14-days incidence is over 7.5 / 1000 residents, there is a daily curfew between 8 pm and 5 am, with the same exemptions applying. description: Starting from May 4, 2002, drivers of lorries with a maximum authorized capacity of more than 2.4 tonnes who do not have symptoms associated with COVID-19 shall complete a solemn declaration on entry into Romania, a specimen of which has been established by the Ministry of Transport, Infrastructure and Communications, specifying the place where they will be located so that they can be contacted in the period between shifts. description: As of  October 29 2020, Romanian state-owned airline Tarom will cancel several international and domestic flights because of the complicated current context. The company said that the flights to and from London would be suspended between November 7 and November 30. At the same time, the flights to and from Brussels are canceled on the days of November 2, 9, and 16, as are those to and from Munich on November 11, 18, and 25. The flights to and from Amsterdam are canceled on November 13, 20, 27, and December 4. The carrier also canceled several domestic flights. Those to and from Oradea are canceled on November 3, 5, 10, 12, 17, 19, 24, 25, and on December 1, 3, 8, 10, 15, while those to and from Satu Mare are canceled on November 4 and November 6. The company said it would contact those who purchased tickets on these dates to offer new flight dates.

description:
Romania, February 12, 2021:
The National Committee for Emergency Situations declares that all persons arriving in Romania from countries/areas/territories with a "high epidemiological risk" shall present a certificate of a negative RT-PCR test for SARS-CoV-2 carried out no longer than 72 hours before the date of entry into the country. The countries/areas/territories currently affected by this measure can be found in the source document "Lista tarilor/zonelor cu risc epidemiologic ridicat, conform Hotărârii nr. 6 din 04.02.2021 a Comitetului Național pentru Situații de Urgență". Exempted from this measure are, among other things, children under 3 years of age and vaccinated people (see article 1 of the source document "HOTĂRÂRE nr. 7 din 04.02.2021"). The ending of this policy is indefinite.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)

description:
Romania, February 12, 2021:
The National Committee for Emergency Situations declares that all persons arriving in Romania from countries/areas/territories with a "high epidemiological risk" shall present a certificate of a negative RT-PCR test for SARS-CoV-2 carried out no longer than 72 hours before the date of entry into the country. The countries/areas/territories currently affected by this measure can be found in the source document "Lista tarilor/zonelor cu risc epidemiologic ridicat, conform Hotărârii nr. 6 din 04.02.2021 a Comitetului Național pentru Situații de Urgență". Exempted from this measure are, among other things, children under 3 years of age and vaccinated people (see article 1 of the source document "HOTĂRÂRE nr. 7 din 04.02.2021"). The ending of this policy is indefinite.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)

description: The Romanian National Committee for Emergency Situations (CNSU) updated the yellow list of countries with high epidemiological risk on 5 March 2021. Travelers arriving from these countries are required to quarantine upon entry for 14 days at home or a stated location. Fifty-two countries are on the list, including many European ones such as Spain, Italy, or the UK, where large communities of Romanians are found. The Republic of Moldova and the United States are also on the list, as is Bulgaria, a favorite tourism destination for many Romanians.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: On May 14, 2020, Romanian National Committee for Emergency Situations updated the list of countries/areas/territories with high epidemiological risk, establishing three codes: red, yellow and green, differentiated on certain criteria according to which people coming from these states may enter Romania. According to the Annex to CNSU Decision 28/2021, the list of countries in the Red Zone includes: Seychelles, Maldives, Bahrain, Uruguay, Cyprus, Cape Verde, Argentina, Lithuania, Costa Rica, the Netherlands, Sweden, Croatia, Turkey, Latvia, Colombia, Andorra, Georgia, Puerto Rico, Mongolia, Slovenia, Paraguay, Kuwait, France, Chile, India, Brazil, Estonia, Belgium, Luxembourg, Nepal, Serbia and South Africa.     In the Yellow Zone: Iran, Canada, Qatar, Germany, Greece, Montenegro, Switzerland, Peru, United Arab Emirates, Trinidad & Tobago, Italy, Austria, Anguilla, Czech Republic, Bahamas, Oman, Hungary, Ukraine, Kazakhsatn, Guyana, Aruba, Denmark, Armenia, Spain, Poland, Palestine, Iraq, Liechtenstein, Bulgaria, Suriname, Bolivia, United States, Lebanon, Tunisia, Northern Macedonia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, and Belarus.

description: From the 19th of June 2020, the Ministry of Transport, Infrastructure and Communications in Romania is launching an application in which travellers entering Henri Coanda Airport, Bucharest have to fill out a questionnaire. This includes contact details and residence of isolation- if necessary. Travellers must then isolate for 10 days. This is targeted towards people travelling from areas of high epidemiological risk, but not to those with similar or less infection rates than Romania. After 10 days of quarantine, travellers are free to leave isolation.

description: On the 21st of January 2020, the Technical-Scientific Support Group for the Management of Highly Contagious Diseases in Romania decided with the Ministry of Internal Affairs to order 1,750,000 protective resources, including PPE, single use gloves and protective masks. They also allocated 110 isolation rooms with negative pressure, 200 cardio respirator machines- 3 sets for the 57 emergency hospitals plus 9 Regional Centres of Infectious diseases, and 2 reserves. They also ordered 150 sets of filters for the isolated rooms, 9000 litres of disinfectant TP1, 9000 litres of TP 2, 5,100 kg of disinfectant for semicritical surfaces, and 5,100 kg of disinfectant for noncritical surfaces.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Voluntary/Recommended but No Penalties

description: On the 26th of February 2020 Romanian Ministry of Health recommended people not take antiviral drugs or antibiotics unless prescribed by their doctor. They said that at the moment, there is no scientific research that shows that the use of antiviral drugs can prevent infection with the new coronavirus (Covid-19). Antibiotics only work against bacteria, not viruses. Thus, scientific research is needed.

description: In Romania, the missions to transport medical equipment from South Korea have started. Approximately 45 tons of equipment, consisting of 100 thousand protective suits, will be brought to the country, between April 13 and 17, 2020, with transport aircraft belonging to the Romanian Air Force. The equipment was purchased from South Korea by the Romanian state, through the National Centralized Procurement Office and the General Inspectorate for Emergency Situations, as part of efforts to combat the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic and will be allocated, depending on needs, to medical personnel from the country and operative crews acting in the field.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: In Romania, as of 20 February 2021, individuals with symptoms should call a family doctor who will make a telephone assessment and decide the way forward. If the doctor decides that a COVID-19 test is needed, the individual will be instructed to call the Public Health Directorate and mention all symptoms. The ambulance service will go to the individual’s house to perform the test, or if the situation requires it, will transport the individual to the hospital. In the case of symptomatic people, the test is done according to the protocol, free of charge. Individuals can also get tested "on request", but this option is for a fee.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

compliance: Voluntary/Recommended but No Penalties

description: On the 10th of June 2021, the Romanian Ministry of Health provides a list of accredited facilities in Romania certified for RT-PCT COVID-19 testing facilities which will prioritize tests for hospitalized patients, individuals suspected of being infected with COVID-19, and individuals who are in a high-risk group. Depending on their availability, they may perform testing on demand and may set the cost of the tests performed on demand. The cost of COVID-19 testing on demand varies between $70 – $100. Test results are delivered by email and text message. Positive test results are also included in the database of the Romanian Department of Public Health.

description:
In Romania, on the 1st of March 2020, the Ministry of Health declared hygiene regulations to prevent the spread of Covid-19:
- People should frequently disinfect the surfaces they come in contact with, with alcohol or chlorine solution, both at home and at work. 
- Avoid touching surfaces that are frequently touched by other people, such as railings, doorknobs, handles, elevators, or access buttons. If they do have to touch these surfaces, protect by using disposable wipes. -- 
- Wash hands with soap and water for at least 20 seconds after any contact with a potentially contaminated surface. 
- Use paper towels, preferably, to wipe hands. 
- Do not touch your eyes, nose or mouth with unsanitized hands. 
- If sneeze or cough, cover your mouth and nose with a disposable tissue, which you should dispose of in the trash immediately.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Voluntary/Recommended but No Penalties

description:
Romania, March 30, 2020:
The Ministry of Internal Affairs imposes a zonal quarantine on the municipality of Suceava and the surrounding area consisting of the following eight municipalities: Adâncata, Salcea, Ipotești, Bosanci, Moara, Șcheia, Pătrăuți and Mitocu Dragomirnei. Exceptions for entering/exiting this locality exist. Reuters: "The quarantine will last until mid-April at the end of the 30-day emergency period". The state of emergency is slated to end on April 15.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries
target_city: Suceava; Adâncata; Salcea; Ipotești; Bosanci; Moara; Șcheia; Pătrăuți; Mitocu Dragomirnei.

description: Romania issued a military ordinance, to enforce a lockdown, as all citizens were forbidden from traveling outside of their homes unless it is for professional purposes or the purchase of essential goods (with several other smaller exceptions). UPDATE: from May 15th, citizens could leave their homes but only travel within their localities. UPDATE: From May 15th 2020, Romania went from a state of emergency to a state of alert, and self-declaration forms will no longer be needed to leave the house
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time)

description: On 28th of October 2020, Romania, the Ministry of Health published an updated the flow of information used in reporting SARS CoV-2 virus infection data. description: On 11th February 2021, the Government of Romania defined “close contact” with COVID-19-infected individuals to facilitate epidemiological investigations. The purpose of defining close contact is to identify individuals designated for 14-day self-isolation following close contact with a COVID-19-confirmed infection. During the period of self-isolation, “close contact” individuals will be tested at the beginning and end of the two-week period. The epidemiological investigation should not lead to the supervised isolation of other individuals not meeting “close contact” criteria.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory (Unspecified/Implied)

description: On the 13th of July 2021, in Romania, everyone who tests positive for coronavirus will be put in touch with an NHS contact tracer to help identify who they’ve been in close contact with. Mobile contact tracing app is also another possibility but it's not in operation now.

description: Starting on 25th February 2020, an online public information campaign was launched on the official Government of Romania Facebook page on the "Prevention and limitation of eventual infection with coronavirus". New, updated information has since been provided daily on the facebook page ( https://www.facebook.com/guv.ro) On the 24/02/2020, this campaign was announced: "The information campaign of the population regarding the infection with COVID-19 will be extended, as well as the individual and collective prevention measures which should be taken and a daily newscast will be drafted regarding the development at international level and possible additional measures taken by the Romanian authorities"

description: In Romania, as of the 21st of July 2020, the TELVERDE line number is functioning, which is a telephone line strictly allocated for informing citizens and is valid for national calls, from Monday to Friday, between 08.00 and 20.00. Government reminds citizens to consider only information verified through official sources and to call for recommendations and other information on the TELVERDE line – 0800.800.358. Romanians abroad can request information about preventing and combating the virus at the line specially dedicated to them, +4021.320.20.20.

description: On the 14th of October 2020, Romanian authorities extend the COVID-19 state of alert until the 15th of November 2020. Under the state of alert, the wearing of face masks remains mandatory on public transport and in enclosed public spaces, such as stores.

description: On the 25th of October 2020, the Romanian Ministry of Health published “Recommendations on responsible social behavior in preventing the spread of coronavirus (COVID-19)” and “Recommended measures to reduce the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic” to spread public awareness. On the 29th of October, The Government of Romania announced the List of infectious diseases for which the isolation of persons is established at their homes. The same document establishes the basic health units in which sick people can be treated with diseases provided in the list of infectious diseases.

description: On 18th January 2021, WHO is working with Romania’s Ministry of Health and health professionals in the country to make telephone consultations more widely available. The aim is to institutionalize telemedicine in Romania and make the service easily accessible to patients during and after the pandemic.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Both Disseminating and Gathering information related to COVID-19
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: As of 20th February 2021, the Romanian official government website for COVID-19 remains current. Daily updates, press releases, current restrictions, statistics, educational videos, hygiene recommendations, advice for parents, and answers to frequently asked questions are provided on the website. Individuals can also subscribe to an official email newsletter for updates and important information. The purpose of the extensions is to highlight official sources of information in order to reduce the effects of 'fake news'. The extension identifies key phrases related to COVID-19 and adds an info box that links to official sources    RoVaccinare is the official platform for information regarding vaccination against COVID-19 in Romania (vaccinare-covid.gov.ro). The website provides news, information on authorized vaccines, the vaccination process in Romania, and corrects misinformation surrounding vaccines.     Additional information is also provided on the Ministry of Health’s website (www.ms.ro/coronavirus-covid-19).
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Voluntary/Recommended but No Penalties

description:
Romania, February 24, 2020:
The Romanian National Institute of Public Health / National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT) provides a list of countries/regions affected by quarantine measures. These include: The Chinese provinces of Hubei (including the cities of Hubei and Wuhan) and Zhejiang (explicitly the cities of Wenzhou, Hangzhou, Ningbo and Taizhou); the Lombardy and Veneto regions in Italy (explicitly the localities of Vo Euganeo, Codogno, Castiglione d'Adda, Casarpusterlengo, Fombio, Maleo, Somaglia, Bertonico, Terranova dei Passerini, Castelgerundo and San Fiorano); Cumiana in the Italian Piedmont region. All travellers from these places are quarantined for 14 days upon arrival in spaces specially designed for this purpose (institutionalized quarantine). Those from other places in mainland China and the Lombardy and Veneto regions need to enter self-isolation for 14 days upon arrival. The policy has no explicit end date.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries
target_city: Wenzhou, Hangzhou, Ningbo and Taizhou (Zhejiang); Vo Euganeo, Codogno, Castiglione d'Adda, Casarpusterlengo, Fombio, Maleo, Somaglia, Bertonico, Terranova dei Passerini, Castelgerundo and San Fiorano (Lombardy/Veneto); Cumiana (Piedmont)
compliance: Mandatory (Unspecified/Implied)

description:
Romania, March 2, 2020:
The Romanian National Institute of Public Health / National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT) provides a list of countries/regions affected by quarantine measures. These include: The Chinese provinces of Hubei (including the cities of Hubei and Wuhan) and Zhejiang (explicitly the cities of Wenzhou, Hangzhou, Ningbo and Taizhou); the Lombardy and Veneto regions in Italy (explicitly the localities of Vo Euganeo, Codogno, Castiglione d'Adda, Casarpusterlengo, Fombio, Maleo, Somaglia, Bertonico, Terranova dei Passerini, Castelgerundo and San Fiorano); the South Korean localities of Daegu and Cheongdo. All travellers from these places are quarantined for 14 days upon arrival in spaces specially designed for this purpose (red zone). Additionally, those from the Italian Emilia-Romagna region and Iran as well as other places in South Korea, mainland China and the Lombardy and Veneto regions need to enter self-isolation for 14 days upon arrival. The ending of this policy depends on decreasing infection transmission rates.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)

description:
Romania, March 8, 2020:
The Romanian National Institute of Public Health / National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT) provides a list of countries/regions affected by quarantine measures. These include: The Chinese province of Hubei; the Italian regions of Lombardia, Veneto (namely Vo Euganeo, Venezia, Padova and Treviso), Emilia-Romagna (namely Modena, Parma, Piacenza, Reggio
Emilia and Rimini), Marche (namely Pesaro e Urbino), Piemont (namely Asti, Alessandria, Novara, Verbano-CusioOssola, Vercelli); the South Korean city of Daegu and county of Cheongdo. All travellers from these places are quarantined for 14 days upon arrival in spaces specially designed for this purpose (red zone). Additionally, those from the Heinsberg District in North Rhine-Westphalia (Germany), Iran as well as other places in South Korea, mainland China and Italy need to enter self-isolation for 14 days upon arrival. The ending of this policy depends on decreasing infection transmission rates.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)

These include: The Chinese provinces of Hubei (including the cities of Hubei and Wuhan) and Zhejiang (explicitly the cities of Wenzhou, Hangzhou, Ningbo and Taizhou); the Lombardy and Veneto regions in Italy (explicitly the localities of Vo Euganeo, Codogno, Castiglione d'Adda, Casarpusterlengo, Fombio, Maleo, Somaglia, Bertonico, Terranova dei Passerini, Castelgerundo and San Fiorano); the South Korean localities of Daegu and Cheongdo. All travellers from these places are quarantined for 14 days upon arrival in spaces specially designed for this purpose (red zone). Additionally, those from the Italian Emilia-Romagna region and Iran as well as other places in South Korea, mainland China and the Lombardy and Veneto regions need to enter self-isolation for 14 days upon arrival. The ending of this policy depends on decreasing infection transmission rates. UPDATE: From March 8, the red zone countries/regions are:

- Hubei Province (including Wuhan City) (China)
- Lombardy region (Italy)
- Vo Euganeo , Venezia, Padova, Treviso (Veneto region - Italy)
- Modena, Parma, Piacenza, Reggio Emilia, Rimini (Emilia-Romagna region - Italy)
- Pesaro e Urbino (Marche region - Italy)
- Asti, Alessandria, Novara, Verbano-CusioOssola, Vercelli (Piedmont Region - Italy)
- Daegu and Cheongdo (Gyeongsangbuk-do)

... the yellow zone countries/regions are:

- other provinces and cities in mainland China
- all other regions and localities in Italy
- other counties and localities in South Korea
- the whole of Iran
- the Heinsberg District in North Rhine-Westphalia (Germany)
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Government Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at a government hotel or facility)
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries
target_province: China: Hubei,Zhejiang; Italy: Emilia-Romagna,Lombardy,Veneto; South Korea: Gyeongsangbuk-do
target_city: Wenzhou, Hangzhou, Ningbo and Taizhou (Zhejiang); Vo Euganeo (Veneto); Codogno, Castiglione d'Adda, Casarpusterlengo, Fombio, Maleo, Somaglia, Bertonico, Terranova dei Passerini, Castelgerundo and San Fiorano (Lombardy); Daegu, Cheongdo (Gyeongsangbuk-do)
compliance: Mandatory (Unspecified/Implied)

All travellers from these places are quarantined for 14 days upon arrival in spaces specially designed for this purpose (red zone). Additionally, those from countries with over 500 confirmed cases of Covid-19 infections (yellow zone) need to enter self-isolation for 14 days upon arrival. The current yellow zone countries are: Australia; Austria; Belgium; Brazil; Canada; Czech Republic; all other places in South Korea and China; Denmark; Switzerland; France; Germany; Japan; Malaysia; UK; Norway; Netherlands; Portugal; Spain; USA; Sweden; Ireland; Israel. The ending of this policy depends on decreasing infection transmission rates.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)
type_sub_cat: Government Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at a government hotel or facility)
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units (other than provincial or city level units) within one or more countries
compliance: Mandatory (Unspecified/Implied)

description:
Romania, March 27, 2020:
The Romanian National Institute of Public Health / National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT) declares that, should HCW [health-care workers; W.H.] come into contact with confirmed cases and they do not present with symptoms, they are asked to self-isolate at home [for 14 days; W.H.] without a test. Diagnostic test will be administered should symptoms appear. The ending of this recommendation is indefinite.

compliance: Voluntary/Recommended but No Penalties

description:
Romania, April 3, 2020:
The Romanian National Institute of Public Health / National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT) provides a list of countries/regions affected by quarantine measures. These include: Austria, Belgium, Switzerland, Italy, France, Germany, Spain, Iran, UK, Netherlands, Spain, USA, Turkey. All travellers from these places are quarantined for 14 days upon arrival in spaces specially designed for this purpose (red zone). Additionally, those arriving from other countries in the world need to enter self-isolation for 14 days upon arrival (yellow zone). The ending of this policy depends on decreasing infection transmission rates. UPDATE: From May 14, more exceptions are added to the obligation of quarantining according to article 1, number 1 of the source document.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)
type_sub_cat: Government Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at a government hotel or facility)
target_geog_level: All countries
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry),Mandatory (Other; please list other enforcement mechanisms in the text entry)

description:
Romania, May 15, 2020:
The Romanian National Institute of Public Health / National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT) provides a list of countries/regions affected by quarantine measures. Currently, all countries in the world are labelled as yellow zone countries, which means that those arriving from these countries need to enter self-isolation for 14 days upon arrival. Exceptions exist. Institutionalized quarantine is still available if needed. The ending of this policy depends on decreasing infection transmission rates. UPDATE: From June 15, individuals from the following countries may enter Romania without the need for quarantining if they are asymptomatic (green zone countries): Austria, Bulgaria, Czech Republic, Cyprus, Croatia, Switzerland, Germany, Greece, Iceland, Latvia, Liechtenstein, Lithuania, Malta, Norway, Slovakia, Slovenia, Hungary.
Also, some new exceptions are added according to article 1, numbers 3 and 4 of the source document "ORDIN nr. 1.080 din 12 iunie 2020".
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)
target_geog_level: All countries
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry),Mandatory (Other; please list other enforcement mechanisms in the text entry)

description:
Romania, July 27, 2020:
The Romanian National Institute of Public Health / National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT) provides a list of countries/regions affected by quarantine measures. Currently, the following countries are labelled as yellow zone countries, which means that those arriving from these countries need to enter self-isolation for 14 days upon arrival: South Africa, Saudi Arabia, Argentine, Armenia, Azerbaijan, Bahrain, Bolivia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Brazil, Cape Verde, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Ecuador, El Salvador, Eswatini, Guatemala, Honduras, Turks and Caicos Islands, United States Virgin Islands, Iraq, Israel, Kazhakstan, Kyrgyzstan, Kosovo, Kuwait, Luxembourg, Northern Macedonia, Maldives, Mexico, Moldavia, Montenegro, Oman, Palestine, Panama, Peru, Puerto Rico, Qatar, Dominican Republic, Russia, Serbia, Singapore, United States of America, Suriname. Exceptions exist. Institutionalized quarantine is still available if needed. The ending of this policy depends on decreasing infection transmission rates.

Romania, August 11, 2020:
The Romanian National Institute of Public Health / National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT) provides a list of countries/regions affected by quarantine measures. Currently, the following countries are labelled as yellow zone countries, which means that those arriving from these countries need to enter self-isolation for 14 days upon arrival: South Africa, Argentine, Armenia, Bahrain, Bolivia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Brazil, Cape Verde, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, El Salvador, Honduras, Turks and Caicos Islands, United States Virgin Islands, Iraq, Israel, Kazhakstan, Kyrgyzstan, Kosovo, Kuwait, Luxembourg, Northern Macedonia, Maldives, Moldavia, Montenegro, Oman, Palestine, Panama, Peru, Puerto Rico, Qatar, Dominican Republic, United States of America, Suriname, Bahamas, Equatorial Guinea, Sint Maarten, Aruba, Faroe Islands and Spain. description:
Romania, August 11, 2020:
The Romanian National Institute of Public Health / National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT) provides a list of countries/regions affected by quarantine measures. Currently, the following countries are labelled as yellow zone countries, which means that those arriving from these countries need to enter self-isolation for 14 days upon arrival: South Africa, Argentine, Armenia, Bahrain, Bolivia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Brazil, Cape Verde, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, El Salvador, Honduras, Turks and Caicos Islands, United States Virgin Islands, Iraq, Israel, Kazhakstan, Kyrgyzstan, Kosovo, Kuwait, Luxembourg, Northern Macedonia, Maldives, Moldavia, Montenegro, Oman, Palestine, Panama, Peru, Puerto Rico, Qatar, Dominican Republic, United States of America, Suriname, Bahamas, Equatorial Guinea, Sint Maarten, Aruba, Faroe Islands and Spain. Exceptions exist. Institutionalized quarantine is still available if needed. The ending of this policy depends on decreasing infection transmission rates. UPDATE: On August 10 at 08:30 pm, Spain is removed from the list of yellow zone countries before the start of the initial policy.

description: From 11th August 2020, travellers from Spain will be placed in a 14 day quarantine in Romania. The place of quarantine will either be the person's home, at a location declared by him or, as the case may be, in a special space designated by the authorities. Quarantine is recommended to all people who live at the same address.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

Currently, the following countries are labelled as yellow zone countries, which means that those arriving from these countries need to enter self-isolation for 14 days upon arrival: South Africa, Argentine, Bahrain, Bolivia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Brazil, Cape Verde, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Turks and Caicos Islands, United States Virgin Islands, Iraq, Israel, Kazhakstan, Kosovo, Kuwait, Luxembourg, Maldives, Moldavia, Montenegro, Palestine, Panama, Peru, Puerto Rico, Qatar, Dominican Republic, United States of America, Suriname, Bahamas, Sint Maarten, Aruba, Faroe Islands, Eswatini, Guam, Malta, Belize and 6 regions in Spain (Aragon, Catalonia, Navarra, Community of Madrid, Balearic Islands, Basque Country). Exceptions exist. Institutionalized quarantine is still available if needed. The ending of this policy depends on decreasing infection transmission rates. UPDATE: On August 29, South Africa, Kazhakstan, Eswatini are removed from the list of yellow zone countries while 4 regions in Spain (Cantabria, Castilla La Mancha, Castilla y León, La Rioja), Andorra, Namibia, Gibraltar and Paraguay are added.

The Romanian National Institute of Public Health / National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT) provides a list of countries/regions affected by quarantine measures. Currently, the following countries are labelled as yellow zone countries, which means that those arriving from these countries need to enter self-isolation for 14 days upon arrival: Andorra, Czech Republic, Luxembourg, French Polynesia, Slovenia, Armenia, Switzerland, Liechtenstein, Croatia, Georgia, Austria, Montenegro, San Marino, Portugal, Northern Macedonia, Jordan, Hungary, Bulgaria, Lithuania, Denmark, Serbia, the US, Curaçao, Sweden, Belize, Jersey, Panama, Palestine, Azerbaijan, Puerto Rico, Netherlands, Cyprus, Slovakia, Turkey, Moldavia, Latvia and Estonia. Exceptions exist. Institutionalized quarantine is still available if needed. The ending of this policy depends on decreasing infection transmission rates.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry),Mandatory (Other; please list other enforcement mechanisms in the text entry)

Romania, February 5, 2021:
The Romanian National Institute of Public Health / National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT) provides a list of countries/regions affected by quarantine measures. Currently, the following countries are labelled as yellow zone countries, which means that those arriving from these countries need to enter self-isolation for 14 days upon arrival: Andorra, Argentina, Aruba, Austria, Brazil, Canada, Colombia, Croatia, Cyprus, Czech Republic, Estonia, France, Georgia, Germany, Gibraltar, Ireland, Israel, Italy, Latvia, Liechtenstein, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malta, Monaco, Montenegro, Netherlands, Panama, Poland, Portugal, Puerto Rico, San Marino, Serbia, Seychelles, Sint Maarten, Slovakia, Slovenia South Africa, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turks and Caicos Islands, United Arab Emirates, United Kingdom, United States of America, Lebanon, Saint Lucia, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, Albania, Guernsey, Bahrain, Chile, Belgium, Uruguay, Bolivia, Eswatini, Maldives, Kosovo, Tunisia, Falkland Islands, Peru, Belarus, Cape Verde, Russia, Dominican Republic, North Macedonia, Kuweit and Malaysia. Exceptions exist. Institutionalized quarantine is still available if needed. The ending of this policy depends on decreasing infection transmission rates. UPDATE: On February 13, 2021, Tunisia, Cape Verde, Canada, Russia and Croatia are removed from the list of yellow zone countries.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
Romania, February 13, 2021:
The Romanian National Institute of Public Health / National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT) provides a list of countries/regions affected by quarantine measures. Currently, the following countries are labelled as yellow zone countries, which means that those arriving from these countries need to enter self-isolation for 14 days upon arrival: Andorra, Argentina, Aruba, Austria, Brazil, Colombia, Croatia, Cyprus, Czech Republic, Estonia, France, Georgia, Germany, Gibraltar, Ireland, Israel, Italy, Latvia, Liechtenstein, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malta, Monaco, Montenegro, Netherlands, Panama, Poland, Portugal, Puerto Rico, San Marino, Serbia, Seychelles, Sint Maarten, Slovakia, Slovenia South Africa, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turks and Caicos Islands, United Arab Emirates, United Kingdom, United States of America, Lebanon, Saint Lucia, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, Albania, Guernsey, Bahrain, Chile, Belgium, Uruguay, Bolivia, Eswatini, Maldives, Kosovo, Falkland Islands, Peru, Belarus, Dominican Republic, North Macedonia, Kuweit and Malaysia. Individuals from these countries with a negative RT-PCR test, carried out no more than 72 hours before boarding or entering the national territory, are to be quarantined for 10 days. Exceptions exist. Institutionalized quarantine is still available if needed. The ending of this policy depends on decreasing infection transmission rates. UPDATE: On February 15, 2021, Moldova, Botswana, French Polynesia, Qatar and Hungary are added to the list of yellow zone countries.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

Currently, the following countries are labelled as yellow zone countries, which means that those arriving from these countries need to enter self-isolation for 14 days upon arrival: Andorra, Argentina, Aruba, Austria, Brazil, Colombia, Cyprus, Czech Republic, Estonia, France, Georgia, Germany, Gibraltar, Ireland, Israel, Italy, Latvia, Liechtenstein, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malta, Monaco, Montenegro, Netherlands, Panama, Poland, Portugal, Puerto Rico, San Marino, Serbia, Seychelles, St. Maarten, Slovakia, Slovenia South Africa, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turks and Caicos Islands, United Arab Emirates, United Kingdom, United States of America, Lebanon, St. Lucia, St. Vincent and the Grenadines, Albania, Guernsey, Bahrain, Chile, Belgium, Uruguay, Bolivia, Eswatini, Maldives, Kosovo, Falkland Islands, Peru, Belarus, Dominican Republic, North Macedonia, Kuweit, Malaysia, Botswana, French Polynesia, Qatar, Hungary. Individuals from these countries with a negative RT-PCR test, carried out no more than 72 hours before boarding or entering the national territory, are to be quarantined for 10 days. Exceptions exist. Institutionalized quarantine is still available if needed. The ending of this policy depends on decreasing infection transmission rates. UPDATE: On February 20, 2021, Bolivia, Botswana, Eswatini, French Polynesia, Germany, Kosovo, Liechtenstein and Malaysia are removed from the list of yellow zone countries while Antigua and Barbuda, Barbados, Jordan and Palestine are added.

Currently, the following countries are labelled as yellow zone countries, which means that those arriving from these countries need to enter self-isolation for 14 days upon arrival: Andorra, Aruba, Austria, Brazil, Cyprus, Czech Republic, Estonia, France, Italy, Latvia, Luxembourg, Malta, Monaco, Montenegro, Netherlands, Poland, San Marino, Serbia, Seychelles, Slovakia, Slovenia South Africa, Sweden, Lebanon, Bahrain, Chile, Belgium, Uruguay, North Macedonia, Kuweit, Hungary, Jordan, Palestine, Bulgaria, Kosovo, Bonaire, Saint Eustatius and Saba, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Moldova, Territory of Wallis and Futuna Islands, Curaçao and Paraguay. Individuals from these countries are to be quarantined for 14 days. Exceptions exist. Institutionalized quarantine is still available if needed. The ending of this policy depends on decreasing infection transmission rates.

description:
Romania, March 19, 2021:
The Romanian National Institute of Public Health / National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT) provides a list of countries/regions affected by quarantine measures. Currently, the following countries are labelled as yellow zone countries, which means that those arriving from these countries need to enter self-isolation for 14 days upon arrival: Andorra, Aruba, Austria, Brazil, Cyprus, Czech Republic, Estonia, France, Israel, Italy, Latvia, Luxembourg, Malta, Monaco, Montenegro, Netherlands, Poland, Puerto Rico, San Marino, Serbia, Seychelles, Slovakia, Slovenia South Africa, Sweden, Turks and Caicos Islands, United Arab Emirates, United Kingdom, Lebanon, St. Lucia, Albania, Bahrain, Chile, Belgium, Uruguay, Maldives, North Macedonia, Kuweit, Hungary, Jordan, Palestine, Bulgaria, Kosovo, Bonaire, Saint Eustatius and Saba, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Isle of Man, Moldova, Territory of Wallis and Futuna Islands. Individuals from these countries with a negative RT-PCR test, carried out no more than 72 hours before boarding or entering the national territory, are to be quarantined for 10 days. Exceptions exist. Institutionalized quarantine is still available if needed. The ending of this policy depends on decreasing infection transmission rates. UPDATE: On March 25, 2021, Albania, United Arab Emirates, Isle of Man, Turks and Caicos Islands, Israel, Maldives, United Kingdom, Puerto Rico and Saint Lucia are removed from the list of yellow zone countries while Curaçao and Paraguay are added.

The Romanian National Institute of Public Health / National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT) provides a list of countries/regions affected by quarantine measures. Currently, the following countries are labelled as yellow zone countries, which means that those arriving from these countries need to enter self-isolation for 14 days upon arrival: Andorra, Aruba, Austria, Brazil, Cyprus, Czech Republic, Estonia, France, Italy, Luxembourg, Montenegro, Netherlands, Poland, Serbia, Seychelles, Slovenia South Africa, Sweden, Lebanon, Bahrain, Chile, Belgium, Uruguay, North Macedonia, Kuweit, Hungary, Jordan, Bulgaria, Kosovo, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Curaçao, Armenia, Bermuda, Croatia, Turkey, Ukraine, Puerto Rico, Argentina, Azerbaidjan, Canada, Cape Verde, Columbia, Costa Rica, Switzerland, Georgia, Germany, Greece, Iran, Latvia, Liechtenstein, Lithuania, Maldives, Mongolia, Oman, Paraguay, Peru, Qatar, US, Anguilla, Bahamas, Belarus, Bolivia, Denmark, Ecuador, United Arab Emirates, Guyana, India, Irak, Kazahstan, Monaco, Nepal, Palestina, Spain, Suriname, Trinidad and Tobago and Tunisia. Individuals from these countries with a negative RT-PCR test, carried out no more than 72 hours before boarding or entering the national territory, are to be quarantined for 10 days. Exceptions exist. Institutionalized quarantine is still available if needed. The ending of this policy depends on decreasing infection transmission rates. description:
Romania, May 14, 2021:
The Romanian National Institute of Public Health / National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT) provides a list of countries/regions affected by quarantine measures. Currently, the following countries/regions are labelled as red zone countries: Seychelles, Maldives, Bahrain, Uruguay, Cyprus, Cape Verde, Argentina, Lithuania, Costa Rica, Netherlands, Sweden, Croatia, Turkey, Latvia, Colombia, Andorra, Georgia, Puerto Rico, Mongolia, Slovenia, Paraguay, Kuwait, France, Chile, India, Brazil, Estonia, Belgium, Luxembourg, Nepal, Serbia, South Africa. The following countries/regions are labelled as yellow zone countries:Iran, Canada, Qatar, Germany, Greece, Montenegro, Switzerland, Peru, United Arab Emirates, Trinidad and Tobago, Italy, Austria, Anguilla, Czech Republic, Bahamas, Oman, Hungary, Ukraine, Kazakhstan, Guyana, Aruba, Denmark, Armenia, Spain, Poland, Palestine, Iraq, Liechtenstein, Bulgaria, Suriname, Bolivia, USA, Lebanon, Tunisia, North Macedonia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Belarus. Individuals from red and yellow zone countries/regions need to go into self or institutionalized quarantine for 14 days. Red and yellow zone countries/regions differ in how exceptions apply. Quarantine measures do not apply to green zone countries/regions. The ending of this policy depends on decreasing infection transmission rates. UPDATE: On May 21, 2021, Anguilla, Armenia, Bahamas, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Bulgaria, Lebanon, Liechtenstein, North Macedonia, Palestina, Poland, Tunisia and Hungary are removed from the list of countries affected by quarantine measures while Botswana, Malaysia and Slovakia are added.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
Romania, June 4, 2021:
The Romanian National Institute of Public Health / National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT) provides a list of countries/regions affected by quarantine measures. Currently, the following countries/regions are labelled as red zone countries: Argentina, Bahrain, Bolivia, Brazil, Cape Verde, Chile, Columbia, Costa Rica, France, Georgia, India, Kuwait, Lithuania, Maldives, Nepal, Paraguay, Seychelles, Sint Maarten, South Africa, Suriname, Trinidad and Tobago, United Kingdom, Uruguay. The following countries/regions are labelled as yellow zone countries: Andorra, Bahamas, Belarus, Belgium, Botswana, Cuba, Denmark, East Timor, Estonia, Greece, Guyana, Iran, Latvia, Malaysia, Mongolia, Netherlands, Oman, Panama, Peru, Puerto Rico, Slovenia, Sri Lanka, Sweden, United Arab Emirates. Individuals from red and yellow zone countries/regions need to go into self or institutionalized quarantine for 14 days. Red and yellow zone countries/regions differ in how exceptions apply. Quarantine measures do not apply to green zone countries/regions. The ending of this policy depends on decreasing infection transmission rates. UPDATE: On June 10, 2021, the list of red and yellow zone countries was updated.

description:
Romania, July 1, 2021:
The Romanian National Institute of Public Health / National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT) provides a list of countries/regions affected by quarantine measures. Currently, the following countries/regions are labelled as red zone countries: Argentina, Bahrain, Botswana, Brazil, Chile, Columbia, Costa Rica, India, Kuwait, Maldives, Mongolia, Namibia, Nepal, Oman, Panama, Paraguay, Saint Kitts and Nevis, Seychelles, South Africa, Suriname, Tunisia, United Kingdom, Uruguay. The following countries/regions are labelled as yellow zone countries: Bolivia, British Virgin Islands, Cuba, Cyprus, Fiji, Georgia, Guyana, Iran, Iraq, Jersey, Kyrgyzstan, Malaysia, Portugal, Russian Federation, Sint Maarten, Trinidad and Tobago, United Arab Emirates, Zambia. Individuals from red and yellow zone countries/regions need to go into self or institutionalized quarantine for 14 days. Red and yellow zone countries/regions differ in how exceptions apply. Quarantine measures do not apply to green zone countries/regions. The ending of this policy depends on decreasing infection transmission rates. UPDATE: On July 8, 2021, the list of red and yellow zone countries was updated.

The Romanian National Institute of Public Health / National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT) provides a list of countries/regions affected by quarantine measures. The countries/regions labelled as red and yellow zone countries/regions can be found in the source document "Lista tărilor/zonelor cu risc epidemiologic ridicat, conform Hotărârii nr. 71 din 16.09.2021 a Comitetului Național
pentru Situații de Urgență". Individuals from red and yellow zone countries/regions need to go into self or institutionalized quarantine for 14 days. Red and yellow zone countries/regions differ in how exceptions apply. Quarantine measures do not apply to green zone countries/regions. The ending of this policy depends on decreasing infection transmission rates.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)
target_country: Albania,Antigua and Barbuda,Armenia,Austria,Azerbaijan,Bahamas,Barbados,Belarus,Belgium,Belize,Bosnia and Herzegovina,Botswana,Brazil,Brunei,Bulgaria,Cabo Verde,Costa Rica,Croatia,Cuba,Cyprus,Dominica,Estonia,Eswatini,Fiji,France,Georgia,Germany,Greece,Grenada,Guatemala,Guyana,Honduras,Iceland,India,Iran,Iraq,Ireland,Israel,Jamaica,Japan,Kazakhstan,Kosovo,Latvia,Lebanon,Libya,Liechtenstein,Lithuania,Malaysia,Maldives,Mauritius,Moldova,Monaco,Mongolia,Montenegro,Nepal,Netherlands,North Macedonia,Norway,Other (please specify below),Palestine,Philippines,Portugal,Russia,Saint Kitts and Nevis,Saint Lucia,Saint Vincent and the Grenadines,San Marino,Serbia,Seychelles,Slovenia,South Africa,Sri Lanka,Suriname,Switzerland,Thailand,Timor Leste,Trinidad and Tobago,Tunisia,Turkey,United Kingdom,United States,Vietnam
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry),Mandatory (Other; please list other enforcement mechanisms in the text entry)

description: On 5th November 2021, passengers traveling with only a negative PCR test and without a valid vaccination certificate or a certificate of recovery from COVID-19 to Bulgaria from Romania will be subject to 10 days of quarantine.

description:
Romania, November 7, 2021:
The Romanian National Institute of Public Health / National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT) provides a list of countries/regions affected by quarantine measures. The countries/regions labelled as red and yellow zone countries/regions can be found in the source document "Lista țărilor/zonelor cu risc epidemiologic ridicat, conform Hotărârii nr. 97 din 04.11.2021 a Comitetului Național pentru Situații de Urgență". Individuals from red and yellow zone countries/regions need to go into self or institutionalized quarantine for 14 days. Red and yellow zone countries/regions differ in how exceptions apply. Quarantine measures do not apply to green zone countries/regions. The ending of this policy depends on decreasing infection transmission rates.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)

description:
Romania, December 10, 2021:
The Romanian National Emergency Committee enacts that individuals entering Romania from EU countries, EEA countries and Switzerland are to be quarantined for 14 days if they are not tested negative for, not vaccinated against or have not recovered from COVID-19. Individuals entering Romania from third-party countries are to be quarantined for 14 days if they can't submit a negative test result upon arrival. The quarantine duration may be shortened to 10 days. In some cases, individuals are exempted from the quarantine obligation. The policy ends on January 8, 2022. Also, the Romanian National Institute of Public Health / National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT) provides a list of countries/regions affected by quarantine measures. The countries/regions labelled as red and yellow zone countries/regions can be found in the source document "Lista cu clasificarea țărilor/teritoriilor în funcție de rata de incidență cumulată". Some quarantine measures differ between yellow and red zone countries/regions.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry),Mandatory (Other; please list other enforcement mechanisms in the text entry)

description:
In Romania on the 6th of December 2021, Romania’s National Committee for Emergency Situations (CNSU), approved the rules (Decision 111/06.12.2021) for placing under quarantine those arriving in the country. The rules are valid between December 10 and January 8.

Those arriving from the European Union, European Economic Area or Switzerland, if they come from a Red zone, they are subject to 14-day quarantine if they have no vaccination certificate or proof of having recovered from Covid-19. Those unvaccinated or without proof of having recovered from the illness are subject to a 10-day quarantine if they hold an RT-PCR test taken less than 72 hours before the entry.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: People who have recovered and/or survived COVID-19,People who are not vaccinated against COVID-19,People who are neither vaccinated nor recovered from COVID-19

description:
Romania, December 5, 2021:
The Romanian National Institute of Public Health / National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT) provides a list of countries/regions affected by quarantine measures. The countries/regions labelled as red and yellow zone countries/regions can be found in the source document "Lista cu clasificarea țărilor/teritoriilor în funcție de rata de incidență cumulată". Individuals from red and yellow zone countries/regions need to go into self or institutionalized quarantine for 14 days. Red and yellow zone countries/regions differ in how exceptions apply. Quarantine measures do not apply to green zone countries/regions. The ending of this policy depends on decreasing infection transmission rates. UPDATE: On December 10, 2021, persons arriving from Member States of the European Union, the European Economic Area or the Swiss Confederation are subject to different quarantine obligations compared to those from third-party countries. Third country nationals are to be quarantined if they do not submit a negative result of an RT-PCR test for COVID-19 carried out not more than 48 hours before boarding (for those travelling by public transport) or entering the national territory (for those travelling by their own means). Individuals from the EU, the EEA or Switzerland can also avert to be quarantined if they are vaccinated against or have recovered from COVID-19.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
Romania, December 10, 2021:
The Romanian National Emergency Committee enacts that individuals entering Romania from EU countries, EEA countries and Switzerland are to be quarantined for 14 days if they are not tested negative for, not vaccinated against or have not recovered from COVID-19. Individuals entering Romania from third-party countries are to be quarantined for 14 days if they can't submit a negative test result upon arrival. The quarantine duration may be shortened to 10 days. In some cases, individuals are exempted from the quarantine obligation. The policy ends on January 8, 2022. Also, the Romanian National Institute of Public Health / National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT) provides a list of countries/regions affected by quarantine measures. The countries/regions labelled as red and yellow zone countries/regions can be found in the source document "Lista cu clasificarea țărilor/teritoriilor în funcție de rata de incidență cumulată". Some quarantine measures differ between yellow and red zone countries/regions. UPDATE: Based on DECISION no. 113 of 10.12.2021, individuals from third countries are to be quarantined for 14 days if they are tested positive for COVID-19 and are not vaccinated against or have not recovered from it. These individuals, if they are not vaccinated against or have not recovered from COVID-19, are to be quarantined for 10 days if they are tested negative for COVID-19. If vaccinated or recovered, they are to be quarantined for 10 days if they are tested positive for COVID-19.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

Some quarantine measures differ between yellow and red zone countries/regions. UPDATE: On December 12, 2021, the list of red and yellow zone countries was updated.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

target_geog_level: All countries

description:
Romania, December 12, 2021:
The Romanian National Emergency Committee enacts that individuals entering Romania from EU countries, EEA countries and Switzerland are to be quarantined for 14 days if they are not tested negative for, not vaccinated against or have not recovered from COVID-19. Individuals entering Romania from third-party countries are to be quarantined for 14 days if they are tested positive for COVID-19 and are not vaccinated against or have not recovered from it. The quarantine duration may be shortened to 10 days. In some cases, individuals are exempted from the quarantine obligation. The policy ends on January 8, 2022. Also, the Romanian National Institute of Public Health / National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT) provides a list of countries/regions affected by quarantine measures. The countries/regions labelled as red and yellow zone countries/regions can be found in the source document "Lista cu clasificarea țărilor/teritoriilor în funcție de rata de incidență cumulată". Some quarantine measures differ between yellow and red zone countries/regions. UPDATE: From December 17, 2021, third country drivers of motor vehicles with more than nine seats, including the driver's seat, which provide for the carriage of passengers, can now be exempted from quarantine measures if they are vaccinated against or have recovered from COVID-19, as an alternative to submitting a negative test result.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry),Mandatory (Other; please list other enforcement mechanisms in the text entry)

Romania, December 19, 2021:
The Romanian National Emergency Committee enacts that individuals entering Romania from EU countries, EEA countries and Switzerland are to be quarantined for 14 days if they are not tested negative for, not vaccinated against or have not recovered from COVID-19. Individuals entering Romania from third-party countries are to be quarantined for 14 days if they are tested positive for COVID-19 and are not vaccinated against or have not recovered from it. description:
Romania, January 9, 2022:
The National Emergency Committee declares that persons arriving in Romania from
countries/territories at epidemiological risk as well as direct contacts of confirmed persons are to be quarantined upon arrival:
a) 10 days for unvaccinated persons or persons who are not in the period between
the 11th to the 180th day after the date of confirmation of SARS-CoV-2 infection;
b) 5 days for vaccinated persons for whom 10 days have passed since the completion of
the vaccination scheme, and for persons who have been confirmed for SARS-CoV-2 infection SARS-CoV-2 virus between the 11th and the 180th day before the date of entry into the country or contact with the infected person. 
The Romanian National Institute of Public Health / National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT) provides a list of countries/regions at epidemiological risk. The countries/regions labelled as red, yellow and green zone countries/regions can be found in the source document "Lista țărilor/zonelor cu risc epidemiologic ridicat, conform Hotărârii nr. 2 din 07.01.2022 a Comitetului Național pentru Situații de Urgență". Red, yellow and green zone countries/regions differ in how exceptions apply. The end of this policy isn't mentioned.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry),Mandatory (Other; please list other enforcement mechanisms in the text entry)

a) 10 days for unvaccinated persons or persons who are not in the period between
the 11th to the 180th day after the date of confirmation of SARS-CoV-2 infection;
b) 5 days for vaccinated persons for whom 10 days have passed since the completion of
the vaccination scheme, and for persons who have been confirmed for SARS-CoV-2 infection SARS-CoV-2 virus between the 11th and the 180th day before the date of entry into the country or contact with the infected person.
The Romanian National Institute of Public Health / National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT) provides a list of countries/regions at epidemiological risk. The countries/regions labelled as red, yellow and green zone countries/regions can be found in the source document "Lista țărilor/zonelor cu risc epidemiologic ridicat, conform Hotărârii nr. 5 din 21.01.2022 a Comitetului Național
pentru Situații de Urgență". Red, yellow and green zone countries/regions differ in how exceptions apply. The end of this policy isn't mentioned.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries

Romania, February 1, 2022:
The National Emergency Committee declares that those arriving in Romania who are not vaccinated against, have not recovered from or have not tested negative for SARS-CoV-2, are to be quarantined for 5 days upon arrival (for details, see article 1 of the source document "HOTĂRÂREA nr. 6 din 31.01.2022"). description: From May 15th 2020 in Romania, private businesses/ economic operators are obliged to ensure that employers can work from home. If the work can not be performed from home then employers must not allow the access of the persons whose body temperature, measured at the entrance to the enclosure exceeds 37.3 degrees. Employers must enforce mandatory disinfection of hands before entering work spaces, and disinfection of surfaces.

description: As of 15 February, the ban on indoor operation for bars, clubs, and disco activities remains in place. Cinemas, performance institutions, indoor restaurants, indoor cafés, and gambling halls are allowed to operate under the following conditions: Without exceeding 50% of the maximum capacity of the space and only in the time interval 6.00-23.00, in the counties/localities where the cumulative incidence of cases in the last 14 days is less than or equal to 1.5/1,000 inhabitants. Without exceeding 30% of the maximum capacity of the space and only in the time interval 6.00-23.00, if the cumulative incidence in the last 14 days of the cases in the county/locality is higher than 1.5 and less than or equal to 3/1,000 inhabitants. It is forbidden if the cumulative incidence of cases is higher than 3/1,000 inhabitants. Currently, the cumulative incidence of cases in the last 14 days is over 3 per 1,000 occupants in Timis and Maramures counties, therefore, cinemas, performance institutions, indoor restaurants, indoor cafés, and gambling halls are closed in these counties.     Museums, art galleries, libraries, and bookstores are open with social distancing and mask requirements. Disinfection of hands and a temperature check is required before entering.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
institution_status: This type of business  ("Restaurants") is allowed to open with conditions

target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Romania banned all mass gatherings of over 100 people from the 11th March 2020 until the 31st of March 2020, with the possibility of prolonging. This includes gatherings for sport, religious, scientific or leisure events. Indoor spaces such as theatres and cinemas were closed, but not shopping malls. 

This decision was announced by the head of the Department of Emergency Situations (DSU), Raed Arafat and Health Minister Nelu Tataru.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

UPDATE: UPDATE: The state of alert on the entire territory of Romania is extended by 30 days until October 15. Private events in open spaces up to a maximum of 100 people are allowed, provided the observance of physical distancing applies. The organization of outdoor public meetings, rallies and demonstrations with a maximum number of 100 participants and provided compliance with the following measures: Mask mearing by all participants as to cover the nose and mouth; Mandatory disinfection of the hands, for all the persons who arrive in the space where they are conducts the rally or demonstration; Maintaining the physical distance of at least 1 meter between the participants and ensuring an area of minimum 4 sqm / person where possible; Disinfection of the hands of the persons who distribute any materials during the rally or demonstration.

description: Authorities of Romanian counties, Hunedoara, Bacău and Lași impose restrictions of mass gatherings in the Horeca area, after the end of the local elections. In Hunedoara county, in 12 localities, the operation of restaurants and bars is no longer allowed. In Bacău county, similar measures were taken in several localities, as well as in Iași county. The restrictions come in the context in which in several localities in the counties the infection rate of 1.5 / 1000 inhabitants has been exceeded in the last two weeks. The measures were taken at the central level and cover the whole country. Additionally, mass gathering events, such as concerts, cultural events, and gambling activities were either prohibited or subjected to curfew (shortened business hours).

description:
On October 5, 2020, Romania announced that "the organization of religious holidays is allowed only with the participation of persons who have their domicile or residence in the locality where the activity takes place, without the participation of persons / pilgrims from other localities."

CNSU decided to limit the attendance to religious events and celebrations amid growing COVID-19 infection cases. Only locals will be allowed to attend religious events held in Romanian localities. This includes the banning of religious pilgrimages. This decision comes prior to the largest pilgrimage in Romania to Lasi which will begin 08-Oct and reach its peak at 14-Oct. Currently no restrictions on free movement in Romania.

description: The organization and outdoor performance of shows, concerts, public and private festivals or other cultural events is allowed in counties/localities where the cumulative incidence of cases in the last 14 days is less than or equal to 1.5/1,000 inhabitants.     Events are limited to 300 spectators with seats located at a distance of at least 2 meters apart. Protective masks are also required.    Activities are prohibited in counties/localities where the cumulative incidence of cases in the last 14 days is higher than 1.5/1,000 inhabitants.    Currently the cumulative incidence of cases in the last 14 days is higher than 1.5/1,000 occupants in Timis, Maramures, Cluj, Brasov, Ilfov, Bucharest, Alba, Hunedoara, Satu Mare, Sibiu, Salaj, and Gorj counties.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Cancellation of a recreational or commercial event
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory (Unspecified/Implied)

description: According to the Decision no.432/8.04.21 of the Romanian government, starting from April 13, 2021, it is forbidden to organize private events (weddings, baptisms, festive meals, etc.) in open spaces, such as, but not limited to, salons, cultural centers, restaurants, terraces, bars, cafes, halls / tents. Additionally, recreational outdoor and sporting activities are prohibited, except for those carried out with the participation of no more than 10 persons not living together.
